Mr. J. D. McLean  
Department of Indian affairs  
Ottawa Can.,

Dear sir,-

Upon coming to Golden Lake today I found that the teacher Miss Schroeder had moved into the new school yesterday, on inquiry I found that the contractors had left the school on charge of the painter, who, told the teacher that the school was ready, and not knowing any better she moved all the old desks et cetra into the new school and began teaching, as the school is almost ready with the exception of the furnace, blackboards, blinds and some painting I decided to leave her in it, I told her however to keep the children in order, so as, not to soil the wall and floor, too much, at least until the school was taken off the contractors hands.

Upon speaking to the contractors about it today they felt very much annoyed at my leaving her in, but, under the circumstances I thought that was the best thing to do.

Trusting that this is to the satisfaction of the department.

I remain

Yours truly

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6133, File 394-5, part 1)
Ottawa, September 9, 1912.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, and in reply I beg to say that the Department regrets that there was any misunderstanding with reference to the occupation of the Golden Lake School by Miss Schruder. However, no doubt she will take good care of it and the Department will take over the building from the contractors upon your recommendation as soon as you make your final report.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. G. Reinke, Esq.,
Ganville, Ont.
Mr. J. D. McLean
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont.

Dear sir,

Replying to your letter # 152205/05 pf September 3/12 I must say that I again have been at the contractors and told them that they should have allowed something for the erection of those closets, but they again claimed that they did not allow anything for them as they had no specifications or plans to figure from, they admit that they have made a mistake by not figuring on those closets but as the closets are now up they are willing to take what the department will allow them.

The school as I mentioned in my letter of the 4th inst is just about completed, the only delay now is the blackboards, the furnace and the blinds, they have them ordered and the furnace is in the basement, but the registers went astray in transit. They expect to have it all completed in about a week or ten days.

Trusting that this will be satisfactory to you

I remain

Yours truly,

R.G.R./G.
Ottawa September 13, 1912.

Memorandum,

Mr Bedley,

I would recommend an additional payment of $25.00 to the Contractor for the Golden Lake School House for the construction of two closets as per plans submitted by the Department which were more elaborate than those figured on by the contractors.

Ottawa, September 14, 1912.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant in reference to the erection of the closets in connection with the Golden Lake School.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of the good work that has been performed on this building by the contractors and the fact that there have up to the present time been no extras whatever in the building, the Department is prepared to allow an additional payment of $25.00, in view of the fact that the plans submitted by the Department for these closets would be more elaborate than those figured on by the contractors. When making your final certificate you will be good enough to show this amount as an extra, stating for what it is allowed.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. G. Reinke, Esq.,
Eganville, Ont.
Eganville, Ont., Sept. 27th, 1912

Mr. J. D. McLean  
Department of Indian Affairs  
Ottawa Can.

Dear sir,

Re Indian School at Golden Lake.

The school is now almost finished; the plumbers are putting in the furnace and the contractors are doing the grading around the building.

The teacher Miss L. Schroeder told me today that she would require some school desks, said she would like to get at least six single #5 desks for primary. If you wish I can get those out in at $3.50 each.

She also complained that there was no place for the teacher to keep her clothes separate from the pupils and consequently I gave an order to the contractors to put a partition in the stationery cupboard and put hat and coat hooks in one part and shelves in the other, allowing them the sum of $4.75.

Trusting that this will be to the satisfaction of the department.

I remain

Yours truly,

R.G.R/G.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6133, File 394-5, part 1)
Ottawa, October 7, 1912.

Sir,

In reply to that portion of your letter of the 27th ultimo in which you state that Miss Schruder, teacher of the Golden Lake School, informed you that she would require some school desks I beg to say that she should make application in the usual way through the office of the Indian Agent, giving the sizes and number of desks required.

Your action in having a partition put in the stationary cupboard for her private use is approved.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. G. Reinke, Esq.,
Eganville, Ont.

Dear sir,

Enclosed please find final certificate for the completion of school on the Golden Lake reserve.

You will notice that there are extras amounting to $18.55. First item, the sewer tile which you instructed me to have but in basement floor. The second item changing two set of steps, you will notice on the plan that there has been an error and the twelve steps were laid out with a 12" rise when I came out the contractors had built them so, so I gave them an order to change and put in one extra step in each set. The third item, sash pull hook which I got them to provide to pull down and shove up sash. Fourth item the partition and shelves in cupboard, as the teacher had no place to keep her clothes I got the contractors to put a partition in the stationery cupboard with shelves in one side for stationery and hat and coat hooks on the other side for the teacher. The fifth item the allowance on the closets of $25.00 which I trust will not need any more explanation.

I am

Yours truly,

R.G.R./G.

There should be provision made in the basement for putting in a stove for the preparation of the winter meals. A T pipe is all that is necessary.
Golden Lake, Oct. 3, 1913

Mr. McKenzie,

Dear Sir,

Mr. Reinke, the Inspector has given me the keys of the new school but permission to move in at any time. Am I at liberty to do so? As I do not wish to make another mistake I will remain in the old building until you advise what to do.

The Special School Inspector has just visited this school, and has recommended simple desks for the new building. Do you think the Department will give us a supply this year? The old ones are in a very poor condition and I hope we will be provided for during the winter months, and if so what provision will be made for the cooking?

Awaiting an early reply and thanking you in anticipation.

Yours respectfully,

Lena M. Schroeder
Eganville, Ont. Oct. 14th, 1912

As the contractors Messrs Tait & Devlin have some heavy obligations to meet by the 19th of this month they would like to get their remittance. Ottawa, November 4, 1912.

Sir,

New desks and a small stove are required for the Golden Lake School. You are hereby authorized to purchase the necessary desks and a suitable stove from the Lee Manufacturing Company, Pembroke, and have them placed in position in the school. You should consult with the teacher as to the sizes of the desks required. A small inexpensive cooking stove with the necessary pipes for the preparation of the mid-day meal is what is required and should be set up in the basement.

Your obedient servant,

S. STEWART

Assistant Secretary.

Eganville, Ont. Nov 29th, 1912

Mr. J. D. McLean
Ottawa Ont.

Dear sir,

Re Indian School at Golden Lake.

On October the 2nd, I took the school off the hands of the contractors and informed you to that effect at the time since then I wrote you saying that the contractors were looking for their check which was deposited with their tender, but, up to date this has not been returned to them, you are aware that this is an accepted check which has been charged to the drawer at the time it was accepted by the bank. Consequently, the contractors are out of the interest of this money and the bank is getting the good of it, surely this must be an oversight.

I trust that you will look into the matter and return the check at your earliest possible convenience.

And very much oblige

Yours truly,

RGR

March 7th, 1919
REPORT OF INSPECTOR FINN ON THE GOLDEN LAKE DAY SCHOOL.

Considerable smoke escapes into the classroom from the furnace at times.

It would be well to have the furnace and pipes cleaned during the midsummer. At the same time it would be well to have the walls tinted and painted.

Date of Inspection, March 13th, 1919.
Ottawa, March 20th, 1919.

Sir,

Inspector Finn, who visited the Golden Lake school recently, states that considerable smoke escapes into the classroom from the furnace, and he recommends that the furnace and pipes be cleaned during the summer holidays.

You will be good enough to have this done at that time.

Kindly submit an estimate of the cost of having the walls of the Golden Lake school, tinted and painted.

Your obedient servant

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

P. Rankine, Esq.
Indian Agent,
Ruby,
Ont.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education

Re Golden Lake Day School.

When the above mentioned school was completed some eight or ten years ago a McClary's hot air coal furnace was installed to heat it. A car-load of coal was purchased after the school was opened and when this supply was exhausted, it was found more economical to heat the school with hardwood, therefore, purchases for this wood were made locally for the past six or eight years. This system of heating has not proven very satisfactory at any time, inasmuch as it is unhealthy for the teacher and the pupils for the following reasons:- In the first place the furnace is so constructed as to burn hard coal only, and since the burning of hardwood blocks creates smoke and odor, the main draft was found to be too small to carry off the fumes sufficiently enough and the result is that the surplus smoke is forced up through the hot air pipes into the class-room which makes conditions there rather abominable throughout the winter months. I would strongly advocate the installation of a wood-furnace in place of the old one, because wood is plentiful on the reserve and is the cheapest in the long run. During my visit to Golden Lake some time ago, I made enquiries as to the probable cost of such a furnace. Messrs. Fluery Bros., of Eganville quoted a price of $175.00, subject to change, for its complete installation. There are, of course, other firms in neighbouring towns who would quote should it be found necessary to call for tenders. This firm (Fluery Bros,) by whom the present furnace was installed do not seem to care about making any allowance for this on a new one, for the reason that it requires to be entirely rebuilt before it can be used again for coal.
There is no woodshed in connection with this school and same would be necessary in order to store the required supply of wood. This could be erected on the school grounds at an approximate cost of about $40.00 as the lumber can be purchased at Golden Lake.

It is customary to have the wood cut early in the summer in order that it may be fairly dry for use in the winter, and this will have to be withheld pending the decision of the Department in the matter of re-installation, as a wood furnace will require a different length of a stick to that used in the coal furnace.

Trusting this matter will receive favourable consideration.

Your obedient servant,

Records Branch.
Ottawa, March 24, 1924.

Sir:

Mr. P. J. Bernard of this Department has reported that the furnace in the Golden Lake Indian Day School is no longer giving satisfaction. It was installed some 8 or 10 years ago and was used for coal, but for the past few years wood has been the fuel. It is reported that Fluery Brothers, of Eganville, have stated to repair it would cost as much as a new wood furnace and they are willing to install a suitable wood furnace for $135.

Please report whether the furnace which this firm will install for $135 is suitable for the purpose and inform me if it would be possible to secure competitive prices.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Ottawa, July 24, 1924.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, furnishing a price at which you can have a wood burning furnace installed in the Golden Lake Indian Day School building. In reply I have to say that you have not stated whether you have obtained prices from any other firm than the one mentioned by you. It is considered that there are a number of firms in Eganville, Pembroke and Renfrew, from whom you could obtain prices for a wood burning furnace of the size and type which would be satisfactory to properly heat this building. It is necessary that competitive prices be obtained from a number of firms, unless you are satisfied that Fluery Brothers of Eganville are the only firm who can supply and install a satisfactory furnace. You should obtain prices as soon as possible and inform the Department of the quotations received.

The Department will expect to hear from you in the course of the next ten days, giving full information as to the prices you have obtained from the various firms handling and installing furnaces. The firms whom you ask to quote should state the type and size of the furnace they will supply.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, September 8th, 1924.

Sir:

I have to draw your attention to official letters of July 24th and August 22nd, last, regarding the installation of a wood burning furnace to replace the present furnace in the Golden Lake Indian Day School. We are informed that this work has not yet been completed. The Department cannot understand why you have not arranged with Fleurie Bros., of Eganville, to install the furnace as instructed. Please be good enough to take immediate steps to have the work completed as soon as possible. In order that there will be no interruption in the classroom work, you should arrange with Fleurie Bros. to do the work on a Saturday. We understand that they can make the change and put in the new furnace in one day. As stated in previous letters, the cost of the furnace and the installation is not to exceed the sum of $140, the amount which Fleurie Bros. quoted for this work. The work should be completed in a satisfactory manner, and properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded by you in favour of Fleurie Bros. covering the cost. It is hoped that it will not again be necessary to repeat these instructions. The Department expects you to give prompt attention in future to school requirements on the Golden Lake Reserve.

I shall be pleased to be informed of the date on which the work of installing the new furnace will be completed.

Your obedient servant,

Madam:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, and in reply beg to inform you that a requisition is being forwarded to the Government Stationery Office to send to your address the classroom supplies asked for.

With reference to the furnishing of a hot drink to the pupils at midday, I beg to say that you may purchase a small quantity of tea and sugar. You should obtain an account, in duplicate, from the merchant from whom you make the purchase, which you should hand to Mr. Agent Rankin to certify and send to the Department for payment. In future all requests for expenditures should be forwarded by you through the office of the local Indian Agent, Mr. Rankin. March 17th, 1930.

I visited the Golden Lake Indian Day school on the 13th instant. 23 pupils out of a roll of 37 were present. There are a few cases of chicken pox among them at the present time. Attendance is irregular.

The school property is in good condition on the whole, a few minor repairs are required. Miss Currier is giving satisfactory service and the pupils are making progress.

The teacher is anxious to continue the hot lunch until the Easter holidays; it has been of very great help to the pupils and I would recommend that the teacher be authorized to continue it until the week of Easter.

Apparently the janitor and truant office - Mat Barnard - is not fulfilling the duties in a satisfactory manner. The teacher was not aware that such a person as a truant officer existed. I understand he has not asked for or been given the names of truants or absentees at any time. The class room has not been scrubbed recently, the teacher informs me that the pupils sweep and dust the class room every afternoon when school is over, this work should be done by the janitor.

The closets are completely filled and should be cleaned right away and kept properly cleaned out at all times.

The pump is out of order and unfit for use. It should be cleaned out, a new pump installed and a cement...
top pot on, the water for school purposes has to be taken from the lake at present, this is both dangerous for the pupils and inconvenient. This work should receive early attention.

Four of the window blinds in the classroom and two in the entrance hall are very dilapidated and should be replaced by new ones.

A few new posts should replace broken ones and the wire needs to be stretched and stapled and the present posts on the school fence need to be cut to uniform height.

The closets need some attention, the seat covers are off the boys closet, the latches of both closets are broken as are also the two front steps. There are no screens in front of the closets. These could be erected at very little cost and I would recommend that the agent be instructed to have screens put up as soon as weather conditions permit.

The school grounds are very rough and untidy, this condition could be much improved if the grounds were levelled a bit and some large stones removed, the brush around the fences cut and a small plot plowed for a flower garden at the front of the building.

A supply of truant officer forms Nos. 139 and 140, also Monthly school report forms No. 19, should be sent to agent Rankins.

Inspector.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the Golden Lake Indian Day School, has drawn the attention of the Department to the need of various repairs, etc., at this school. He states that the closets should be cleaned out and placed in a good, sanitary condition. The seat covers are off the boys' closet and the latches on both are broken, also the two front steps. The Inspector recommends that screens be placed in front of the closets. He states that these could be erected at very little cost. You should therefore arrange, as soon as weather conditions permit, to have the necessary repairs carried out, viz.: repair the seats, have new latches installed on the doors, the front steps repaired, screens erected and the closets cleaned. The Department will expect you to see that this work is satisfactorily completed and that all costs for the purpose are kept as low as possible.

The Inspector states that the pump is out of order. I have to request you to have the well cleaned out, a new pump installed and a cement top put on. This work should be done as soon as weather conditions permit. The Department will also expect you to see that a satisfactory job is completed in placing the pump in good condition and as inexpensively as possible.

You should arrange for the purchase and installation of four window blinds of the size required for the classroom and two blinds in the entrance hall.

THE Griffith bowl, seat and lid, and nickelled vent pipe attached to bowl, are the only parts of the equipment visible in the toilet room. These parts, therefore, are made with particular attention to elegant appearance in design and finish.

The bowl is designed especially for our system. It is pure white vitreous china, which is made of the celebrated English ball clay. The china is perfectly fired, producing a vitreous body guaranteed to stand the Ink Test. A good vitreous china bowl will not absorb ink; a poor one will. The bowl has a glossy, smooth surface. Nothing but "firsts" are passed by the inspectors or accepted at our factory. "Firsts" are bowls without a flaw in form and finish.

The Griffith bowl is designed perfectly to meet the requirements of a chemical toilet. The diameter and the position of the seat are based on accepted standards with respect to anatomical requisites.

The bowl will last indefinitely. The base of the bowl is oval and fits into an oval funnel. The bowl can be placed in any position with reference to the tank.

The seat and lid are similar to the seat and lid of bowls of the best flush toilets. The fittings are heavily nickeled.

The four-inch nickelled vent pipe in the toilet room matches the white china bowl. It runs through the ceiling.

The Tank

Griffith Chemical Toilet Tanks are made of 14 gauge Copper Bearing Steel. To make doubly sure of the lasting qualities of our Tanks, all metal parts below the floor line, are heavily coated with plastic enamel.

Plastic enamel is a coating that water, air, alkali or gases do not affect. This enameling process is a feature in the manufacture of Toilet Tanks.

That is one reason why Griffith Toilets are the best that science has devised and given to the user, insuring a toilet of long service.

The durability of Griffith Tanks is certain and the Griffith Service stands back of each Griffith-made product.

Griffith Chemical Toilets
the result of years of skilled research

The T. G. Griffith Limited research department has spent years in testing and experimenting with new ideas, investigating the latest developments in sanitary improvements and seeking always to keep their own system up to the highest standard of excellence that modern requirements call for. We believe that these years of endeavour have resulted in our being able to offer the people of Canada the most sanitary and efficient chemical toilet system at the least cost. Griffith Chemical Toilets are the only chemical toilets entirely manufactured and financed in Canada.
Sewage Disposal Conditions that exist in Rural Districts

Just glance at these pictures from life of two old-fashioned outhouses in Winter and Summer. It is almost incredible that such places should still be in use, but they will soon be entirely abolished. They breed flies that carry filth and disease into the home and on to the food; they allow seepage of raw sewage, alive with germs, which contaminates the water of adjacent wells; they are inconvenient uncomfortable, unsightly and nauseating; a menace to physical health and an eyesore to the neighbourhood.

Dear sir,-

I have your letter of October 28th 1938, file No 11-1-5, regarding a report on the Golden Lake Indian day school by Inspector Anderson,

I have to say that I recommend a set of smoke pipes for the furnace and about one length of heat pipes that is from the furnace to the floor upstairs.

I have mentioned for the estimates for 38-39 $100.00 for painting school. The School should be painted on both the inside and outside on the inside to brighten up the room as between smoke and dirt the school is a very dull colour, and on the outside to preserve the sheeting as nearly all the old paint is washed off the clapboards.

I recommend a new set of toilets for the school that is the new kind built in the school nearly all the rural schools around her have them.
these outdoor toilets have been condemned in all rural schools.

With regard to fire wood supplied by Mr Matt Bernard. Last year Matt cut about 25 cords of poplar for the school last fall about the time fires were necessary I looked the wood over again, and it was dry as it was piled where the sun could get at it. This wood appeared to me to heat the school alright when the furnace was fired properly. Matt usually starts the fire about 7:30 in the morning, sometimes when the teacher gets to the school the fire has burned out and naturally the school is cold especially when the temperature is below zero, and I know this has happened. Poplar will not last as long as hard wood, but I believe it would heat that school if the furnace is fired right, I must say that the teacher does not possess the ability to make fires, that is in my opinion. She made very few complaints to me this winter, about being cold, only once or twice and I took the matter up with Matt. The only difference I can see about Matt supplying poplar or hard wood such as elm and ash is that it takes more soft wood to keep the school warm. I should have answered your letter sooner, but I wanted to see how the school would be kept this Winter. Matt has a supply of mixed wood prepared for the school for next year cut now.

Your obedient servant

Indian Agent.

Dear sir,-

I have your letter of March 30th regarding the painting of the Golden Lake Indian day School.

I beg to say that in my estimates for expenditure on repairs to Building and Works for the year 1938-39, I put in a grant for paint for the School. I had in mind at that time painting the outside of the School, however last Winter Inspector Anderson recommended painting on the inside among other things. In the estimates for 1938-39 stated $100.00 and figured that this would cover the cost of painting the outside of the school, but I know that it will not do both the inside and outside.

With regard to your letter of March 30th the third paragraph, regarding Indian labour. I am unable to recommend this as we have no Indian painters on the Reserve and inexperienced painters would be more expensive and likely do an unsatisfactory job.
To paint both the inside and the outside of the School would likely cost close to $200.00, I would recommend this grant however if only $180.00 one hundred dollars is available this year, I would recommend the painting of the inside of the school, because it certainly needs it.

I believe the best price on the job could be obtained by taking tenders, however if this is not desired, I would recommend John Grand of Eganville, as I see his work, and I know that he can paint.

Mr Anderson recommends Cream colour for walls and ceiling light buff for wainscoting, and varnish for the floors. The walls should be thoroughly washed treated and filled. The walls should get about three coats of paint. I estimate that it will take about five gallons of paint to do the walls and ceiling once.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sirs,

I have brought to the attention of the Indians Department the unsanitary condition of our local reserve primary school some time ago, but so far nothing has been done to improve conditions for the beginning of the school year.

There are about 30 or 35 pupils attending at present time. The pupils are using two separate toilets which are in desperate condition. In the school room the pupils are all drinking from an open water pail and only one cup and on account of the health condition of some of the families' families on the reserve this constitutes a real danger to the general health of our children.

I might state that Mr. Anderson, district separate school Inspector, has recommended changes covering the above conditions and he has also suggested that the school building should be
thoroughly cleaned and painted.

As I stated before these matters have been taken up with officials of the Indian Department some time ago and the local Indian Agent has attended our council meetings in which these matters have been discussed and recommendations for the improvement of conditions in our school passed by our Council were, we understand, to be forwarded to the Indian Dept by the attending local Agent.

I trust that your Department will see fit to have an investigation of the conditions here by one of your Officials as soon as possible and I feel sure that on your report the Indian Department will carry out the improvements we feel are absolutely necessary for the health of our children.

Yours Truly,

Wm Tennessee

Chief of Golden Lake Indian Reserve.
P.S.

I might state that since I have written this letter, I have found out that the Indian Department has granted a paint job on the inside of our school "only." Nothing Else.

W.T.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Hoey

Re: Indian School, Golden Lake

The boys' closet is in a filthy condition. They are in the habit of using the seat to stand on because it is too high from the ground for use as intended.

Dear sir,

I have your letters of May 16th and June 3rd, file No 11-1-5, regarding a purchase of 6 brooms for the Golden Lake Indian School.

This is by no means a new arrangement as it has been done since the present school was built about twenty five years ago. Dear Mr. Farrell:

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

I beg to submit the following report covering my visit to Golden Lake Agency on May 26th and May 27th.

SCHOOL

A good frame building in good repair. Mrs. George is proving to be an excellent teacher who is insisting on much better discipline than the pupils have ever been accustomed. There are 30 pupils on roll with an average attendance of 24. Isabel Benoit a pupil has not been attending school for no reason. Her mother was visited and warned. She promised to send Isabel to school. Her attendance that afternoon was noted. Minor repairs to desks and shelves are necessary at an estimated cost of $12.00. This repair work is recommended as necessary. Desks require re-spacing and placement on new runners. The supplying of a better grade of fire wood was discussed with Matt Barnard who has supplied the wood for a number of years. He promised to have the quality improved. This complaint is not of a serious nature. Outside toilets should be cleaned at least twice a year instead of once as at present, and lime used throughout the year.

Dear Sir:

RE - Golden Lake Indian Day School.

During the past week the teacher of the Golden Lake Indian Day School reported that some person had gotten into the school during the weekend of Oct. 31st, and had ransacked the school. After a thorough checkup there did not seem to be anything missing.

I visited the school and found that although the windows had locks on them, none of the locks worked as the top sash of each window seems to have slipped down.

I would recommend that these sashes be forced back into place and blocks be nailed under them to keep them there. Also that a board be placed in a slanting position in each window so that the cold air will be forced to go upward above the level of the children's heads when the windows are open.

Also I would recommend that a clock be supplied to this school. Miss McNulty, the teacher, has been using her alarm clock during the past month. This is very inconvenient for her as she has to carry her clock to school in the morning and back home at night. She tells me that a clock is a necessity in the method she uses to teach.

Hoping for an early reply, I remain,

Your Obedient Servant,

Mr. H. P. Ruddy, Indian Agent, Golden Lake, Ontario

I am in receipt of a report from Mr. J. T. Anderson, Public School Inspector, on the Golden Lake Indian Day School, which reads in part as follows:

"I would urge that the school be given a good scrubbing and the out-houses a thorough cleaning as soon as possible. It would be well, also, to make certain of an adequate supply of good dry wood before winter sets in."

It is of the utmost importance that these matters, relating to the operation of our schools, be brought to our attention, not by the public school inspector, but by our own agent.

This will be your authority to purchase the wood necessary for the heating of the school. It is noted from the records that last year we purchased 10 cords of hardwood at $6.00 per cord and 2 cords of kindling wood at $10.00.

I have been wondering if it would be possible to have the Women's Club take an active interest in the school. Would it be possible to have a couple of these women or a couple of the senior pupils scrub the school intermittently? The scrubbing of a school floor and the dusting of a school should form an indispensable part of an Indian pupil's education. Nothing he, or she, can learn in the school is of greater importance than this. I have been wondering, also, if there are scrapers outside the school door and if these boys are taught by the teacher to clean their feet before entering the classroom. Indian day and residential schools can be kept clean. I have visited Indian day schools, in charge of Sisters, that were simply spotless.

In respect to the out-houses, these should be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times and chloride of lime should be used for this purpose. These are matters that you might well discuss with the teacher, and, if you consider it advisable, with the members of the women's organization. We are, as you know, taking a special interest in the welfare and progress of the Golden Lake Indians, and the program we have in mind should certainly include the school.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

RE-Golden Lake Indian Day School, painting and fencing.

I acknowledge your letter of July 15th, and wish to inform you that the cost of paint for the Indian Day School will be within the fifty dollars mentioned in your letter of authority. In fact I believe that we will have enough left to get oil for the floor. I have made arrangements with Mr. Knuth a local merchant to supply us with Canada Paint Company's first quality paint. In our discussion of the paint it was suggested that the school be trimmed with green. I am inclosing a colour sample of the shade of green that I ordered. I hope that this shade is satisfactory.

With regard to the fencing of the school grounds I would suggest that some kind of heavy, meshed lawn fencing be supplied for the front while the side and back be fenced with ordinary page wire. I am inclosing a requisition for this wire as it cannot be bought locally. I believe that I can get enough fence posts on the Reserve to do this job.

I will have the toilets moved further back so as not to be so conspicuous from the road. There should be new screens for these toilets and these will require 120 bd. ft. dressed lumber and 80 bd. ft. 2x4 scantling.

p.t.o.
A cement walk from the gate at the road to the school steps (a distance of 50 ft.) would improve the appearance of the grounds. Also it would be much easier to keep a path open in the winter months.

Michael Bernard, an Indian, will do this work. He is the same man that was overseer at the building of the roothouse last year, and he also built the chick brooder this spring. He will charge .60¢ per hour to paint and .45¢ per hour for any other work that has to be done.

Hoping that you will give these suggestions your consideration, I remain,

Your obedient servant,

H. P. Ruddy
Indian Agent.

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

RE-SCHOOL HOLIDAY ON JUNE 9TH, 1944.

Miss McNulty, the teacher of the Golden Lake Indian Day School, informs me that June 9th has been proclaimed a holiday and would like to know if this affects her school. In circular C-150-48 (SCHOOL YEAR AND HOLIDAYS ACADEMIC YEAR 1944-45) June 9th is not mentioned as a holiday.

I would like to get authority to install Yale Locks on the two outside doors on the Indian Day School. The locks that are on these doors can be opened with skeleton keys and although nothing has been taken we have reason to believe that someone has entered the school at night recently. Also the locks on some of the windows are not in working order due to the fact that the upper sashes have slipped down. I would like authority to have these repaired at the same time.

Hoping for an early reply I remain,

your obedient servant,

H. P. Ruddy,
Indian Agent.

Sept. 11th, 1944.

Mr. McGill,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.

Dear Sir:

At some few times during the past year, Dr. McCann has been interviewing you re. quarters for the teacher at Golden Lake Sch. He was assured, I believe, that this matter would be attended to.

Now, I have returned for the yr 1944-45 to find nothing done. It so happens that I have developed a foot condition from the two mile walk every day — and for which I have had to have treatment over the holidays. While it has cleared up, I am assured it will return with continued walking.

In addition, it is difficult getting quarters in the village. The pop. is practically German and so decidedly pro-German that living with them is most unpleasant. There are no conveniences or privileges yet I must pay as much as in larger centres.

I have the present room until the end of Sept. and no longer, nor do I know of
any other. I hope the Dept will make something ready for me.

Mrs. Davalley says the kitchen of her former home could be made available by a partition. The front and upstairs could still be used by the club. The necessary furnishings and fuel would be the only expense.

Of course the better plan would be to build on the end of the school—three small rooms—and convert some of the school heat. There is extensive building going on at Eganville—possibly this could be prepared in short order.

I would appreciate something done, as a teacher cannot work under existing conditions to advantage.

Thanking you Mrs. McGill, in anticipation, and may I have an early reply.

I am,

Very Sincerely,

Margaret MacNulty,
Golden Lake School.
Ottawa, September 15, 1944.

Miss M. MacNulty, Teacher, Indian Day School,
Golden Lake, Ontario.

Your letter of September 11, addressed to Dr. McGill, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

You are probably aware that no Indian day or residential schools and no teachers' residences have been built by this Department at any time in recent years. As a matter of actual fact, none of the schools such as the large Indian day school at Caughnawaga have been rebuilt since they were destroyed by fire. When the Government's immediate post-war building program is organized, I am of the opinion that schools destroyed by fire throughout the Dominion will have a first claim, and rightly so, on our resources.

The desirability of erecting a teacherage at Golden Lake has been reviewed on a number of occasions since I entered the Department 8 years ago. No action has been taken, however, for the simple reason that a great many teachers, perhaps the majority, prefer to live off the reserve where at all possible. You will realize, therefore, that we hesitate to proceed with the construction of a building in which your successor or successors might refuse to reside. However, I have noted with interest the suggestion contained in the last two paragraphs of your communication. It is my intention to ask Mr. Morris to investigate this matter at the time of his next visit to Golden Lake.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

RE - REPAIR OF GOLDEN LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

I wish to inform you that I repaired the Golden Lake Indian Day School as per your instructions contained in your letter dated July 10th, 1944.

We scraped and varnished the desks, repaired the windows so that they may be locked also put in new glass, painted the draft boards and library, shortened the benches, repaired the broken glass in the door, and replaced broken glass in the storm windows, built a cement form around the well and cleaned the well out.

The way that the windows are built we were unable to put hinges on the transoms. So far I have not been able to get Yale locks for the doors as these open outwards and the regular Yale locks are for doors that open in. I was unable to get fasteners for the gates but a local blacksmith is going to make them.

Please find attached Voucher No. 134 for groceries and etc. given to Indians for labour on this job along with pay sheets covering this voucher. The material that was used is also included in this voucher.

RE-Repairing roof on Golden Lake Indian Day School.

In the Minutes of the Council meeting held on March 17th a motion was passed requesting that the roof on the Golden Lake Indian Day School be repaired this year.

The roof on the school is of wooden shingles and although they didn't look bad last year, when the snow went off the roof this spring they seem to have cupped up, especially on the South side, and there is a possibility that the roof may leak after the sun gets hot and dries the shingles out during the summer.

Therefore I would recommend that the old shingles be taken off and new ones put on during the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

H. P. Ruddy,
Indian Agent.

CONSTRUCTION OF
INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Dear Sir:

I would ask the Department for authority to hire a Bulldozer for the excavation of the basement of the new Indian Day School which will be built on the Golden Lake Reserve. The cost of this operation would be approximately fifty dollars.

I would also ask for authority to hire a truck, or trucks, for the hauling of gravel, stone and etc., for the construction of the foundation of the above mentioned building, for the hauling of building material, and other incidental hauling during the construction period. The wages paid to truckers in this locality at present is two dollars per hour. I will endeavour to keep the cost of trucking down to a minimum by using the Department owned team of horses whenever possible.

I would also ask for authority for the payment of the following rates of wages for the labour. Foreman-Carpenter, $1.00 per hour; first grade carpenters, 75¢ per hour; second grade carpenters, 65¢ per hour and ordinary labour 50¢ per hour.

Yours very truly,

H. P. Ruddy,
Indian Agent.

Golden Lake Indian Day School

The Department approves the following expenditures necessitated by the construction of the new day school on the Golden Lake Reserve:

(1) Approximately $50.00 to cover the hiring of a bulldozer for the excavation of the basement.

(2) The expenditures necessitated for the hiring of a truck or trucks to haul gravel, stone, etc., required for the foundation of the school.

It is understood that the local prevailing wage for truckers is $2.00 per hour and that you will endeavour to keep the cost of trucking down to a minimum by using the departmental team of horses where possible.

The Department also approves the payment of the following rates of wages to the Indians who will be employed on this job:

(a) Foreman carpenter - $1.00 per hour,
(b) First grade carpenters - 75¢ per hour,

Dear Sir:

Attached herewith is a requisition for the material required for the construction of the Standard Combined One Classroom Indian Day School with Teacher's quarters on the Golden Lake Reserve.

I think that this requisition includes all of the material needed with the exception of the heating system and gravel and stone for the foundation. I understand that the installing of the heating system will be by sub-contract which will be taken care of at a later date. The gravel may be purchased locally from a white farmer and the cost will be approximately ten cents per yard plus the cost of hauling. The only cost of the stone used, will be the hauling.

In the requisition for Hardware I quoted the number of sash balances as given in the list of material (Index No. 837), but I am of the opinion that this number is required for a Two room school with living quarters. Yours very truly,

MEMORANDUM

Re: Golden Lake Indian Residential School,
Golden Lake, Ontario.

In connection with Major Mackay's memorandum of November 19th bearing your notation of the 22nd instant, together with tenders, manufacturers catalogue data, and requests for quotations with reference to a gravity warm air furnace for the above, you are advised as follows:

Since it is established that wood is to be used as fuel, the choice of a furnace for this job narrows down to one of several units offered by the Pease Foundry Company Limited.

After considering the units listed in their pamphlets, it is recommended that their wood burning furnace number 21 having a rated capacity of 40,000 cu. ft. and 1,100 square inches of warm air leader pipe area, be selected.

The Pease Foundry have not submitted a price, but from the accompanying list, shows this unit with casing to be listed at $282.00 with a 20% discount which brings the net price to $225.60 f.o.b. Toronto, no sales tax.

We are returning herewith all tenders and accompanying pamphlets, requests for tenders, etcetera.

(sgd.) F.T. Mills

Dear Sir:

Further to our telephone conversation of this morning, I wish to advise you that I have discussed the matter of beds with the teachers of the Golden Lake Indian Day School and they have decided that two single beds would be the better for the living quarters. Therefore I would ask you to order two single beds instead of one double bed. These along with whatever other bedroom furniture the Department allows may be forwarded immediately.

With regard to the furniture for the living room and kitchen I might say that the only item received so far is the cooking range. Memorandum:

Colonel B. F. Neary,

In a recent inspection trip to Golden Lake Indian Reserve, Indian Agent Ruddy advised that he expected there would be certain surpluses of building materials after the school is completed. I requested him to make a list showing the quantities and types when the work on the school is finished, then this would be sent to your office for advice as to what should be done with the surplus. In my opinion, it should be turned over to Welfare to be used for the building of Indian houses.

Mr. Ruddy also mentioned that Dr. Reeves was very anxious to have a small room made available in the basement where Indians could be examined and treated on his regular visit to the Reserve. Materials are available to do this job, but it would cost approximately $50. for the labour. I would recommend that Mr. Ruddy be instructed to have the work done and payment be made out of the School vote. (You will recall I discussed with you on the telephone the advisability of charging the Medical Health Services for the materials and labour and you stated that you thought that the Schools would pay the small cost to make the space available.

Mr. Ruddy also showed me a large cupboard, which was manufactured and delivered to be installed in the kitchen, but said that he thought the cupboard would take up too much room, as the space was rather small. However, he should be instructed to have the cupboard installed, as provided in the specifications.

J. E. Morris,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for the Province of Ontario.
February 7, 1949.

Mr. H.P. Ruddy,
Assistant Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Golden Lake, Ontario.

Golden Lake Indian Day School

The furniture required for your school has now all been ordered, and parcels should start reaching you in the near future.

I understand that you are preparing a list showing quantities and type of surplus materials so that a decision can be reached as to their disposal.

As you are aware, our plans call for a small First Aid room in the basement. Mr. Morris advises me that with an expenditure of approximately $50.00, we can have this room set up for use by Dr. Reeves. You may have this done. With regard to the cupboard, our plan is to provide a built-in kitchen of a small size with all meals being eaten in the combined living-dining room. I appreciate that the teacher may want to eat in the kitchen, but unfortunately, the design does not provide for this accommodation.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

Attached herewith are the timesheets for weeks ending March 19th and March 26th, 1949 for labour on the new Golden Lake Indian Day School.

These sheets cover the cost of labour while painting the inside of the classroom, the two cloakrooms and the hallway to the basement; the painting of interior of all the windows and the construction of part of one toilet.

We still have one toilet (the boy's) to build, the floors in the classroom and cloakrooms to varnish and part of the outside painting to do. The painting of the window sash goes very slow and will take up more time than the rest of the painting. While this work will run over into the new fiscal year this could not be helped, as there was no advantage in taking on extra men because, due to the weather conditions, they could not do this work. We will also have some levelling of the ground to do as soon as the frost is out.

With regard to the amount of money it will take to do the rest of the work I would say that if $250.00 was transferred to Vote 516-10-491 it will definitely be sufficient. I would ask you to forward an advance of this amount at your earliest convenience.

Yours very truly

H. P. Ruddy,
Indian Agent.

We are not yet issuing cheques on this appropriation, but hope to do so within a week or ten days. At that time an accountable advance of $250.00 will be forwarded to you.

PP/ST

Bernard F. Neary,

Gull Bay School.
Sir,

The Indians of Bull Bay Lake Region have asked for a school and I would recommend that their request be granted. They counted thirty-one children of school age who they claim live in the village all year.

The Indians would take out the logs for this building and put it up if the government provided food supplies while they are so engaged.

It would be necessary to buy here the finishing material such as shingles, tar paper, mails windows, doors and etc., not over $100.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent Brown of Port Arthur has written the Department saying that the Gull Bay Band, Lake Nipigon, have asked for a school. He states that there are 31 children of school age who live in the village all the year round. The Indians would take out the logs for the building and put it up if the government would provide food supplies while they are so engaged. The only additional cost for the building would be about $100.00 for shingles, tar paper, nails, windows, doors, etc.

Mr. Paget, who visited this locality lately, informs me that a school is badly needed there.

If this application is approved authority might be given for getting out the logs and arrangements made for sending in the other material required, so that the school would be ready for occupation early next year.

I beg to enclose requisition for Shell Bay School. Kindly have these articles shipped to Rippon by C.O.R. as quickly as possible.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing a resolution passed by the members of the Gull Bay Band requesting the Department to re-open the day school on the Gull Bay Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that the Department cannot approve of the re-opening of this school owing to the fact that the Indians are away at long periods from the Reserve each year. Your suggestion that these children be sent to St. Joseph's Boarding School at Fort William is considered the best means available for the providing of educational facilities for the children of Gull Bay. You should endeavour to influence the Indian parents to allow their children to enter St. Joseph's Boarding School. We feel that if the day school was re-opened the attendance would be so irregular that it would not warrant the department in incurring the expenditure involved in paying the teacher's salary and other expenses. Please inform the Indians interested accordingly, also that the Department will authorize the admission of any of the children they may send to the Boarding School at Fort William. Applications and certificates of health on the forms for that purpose should be forwarded if any children are sent. All particulars on the form should be filled in and they should be properly signed in the presence of a subscribing witness.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Burk, Indian Agent, Port Arthur, has discussed the day school situation at Pic, Sand Point, Mobert and Gull Bay. At one time or another schools were in operation at all four of these Reserves. Mr. Burk is of the opinion that there will be an agitation for the reopening of these schools. He considers it advisable to experiment with one Reserve, and suggests Pic as the most promising. A summer school might be granted here, as there is an old schoolhouse. Desks would be required and, if the work was continued during the winter months, arrangements would have to be made to put the building in good shape.

I have not suggested to Mr. Burk that he advocate commencing a school at Pic, but if the demand is strong enough we might favourably consider the matter.
Sir,

Regarding the school situation in this agency I beg to submit the following report:

At Gull Bay Reserve there are between 30 and 35 children of school age. The parents of these children have built permanent homes and are most anxious to have school facilities for their children on this Reserve. The old school at Gull Bay has not been opened for a number of years.

During the last three years on every visit to Gull Bay this matter has been brought to my attention, and I have taken no action owing to the fact that I have hoped to enroll the children in the St. Joseph's Boarding School. I find here, as on all other Reserves in this Agency, a strong desire on the part of the parents to have their children with them, as well as a growing prejudice against Boarding Schools. I have done all in my power to encourage the parents to send their children to the Boarding School but with little success.

As there are so many children on the Gull Bay Reserve receiving no education I would also recommend the erection of a new school and residence at this point.

The Indians on the above mentioned Reserves are gradually taking up farming and have built permanent homes. The Indian Day Schools not only educate the children but the whole family in modern way of living and in sanitary habits. I would recommend that provision be made in the estimates for the erection of schools and teachers' residences at Pic, Sand Point and Gull Bay Reserves.

The approximate cost of these buildings would be $20,000.00.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

If funds could be supplied to employ a suitable instructor, quilt work, basket work, bead work and braid bark work could be taught, and the articles they make be offered for sale, helping these Indians to be self-supporting.

On this reserve, the Indians have
constructed in spare time, a good log building, two storeys high and which is 30 by 40 feet in size, with the hope that the department would consider using it for a hospital.

The question of drinking water on the reserve is of utmost importance. At present the water tastes so bad that one can hardly drink it without it turning the stomach. We go out about 600 feet on the bay for it, but it is terrible. There is no well on the reserve and I suggest the department have two wells dug to serve the twenty-five families living here.

With regards to your 'Follow-Up System', I am enclosing a list of the names of pupils who have left school since I was appointed teacher and hope what information I have and send will be of use to you.

I trust you will give these suggestions your kind consideration.

Sir:

I beg to refer to our verbal conversation of recent date regarding the proposition of appointing a qualified nurse in an Indian Day school, for this term.

As it is practically impossible to secure qualified teachers at this time, I would strongly recommend that a registered nurse be appointed to the Gull Bay Indian Day school.

The present Gull Bay teacher could be transferred to the McIntyre Bay school, where there is a vacancy.

The question of employing a nurse has been discussed very often for this reserve, but unfortunately the funds have not been available.

The suggestion, as made by me, during my recent visit to Ottawa is as follows. A nurse be employed, who is capable of teaching a certain amount of the school work. This work would be given in the morning and the afternoon would be used for various forms of health training, which I will outline as follows:

1. The proper methods of cooking plain foods, particularly vegetables and soup.
2. Keeping the body and clothing clean.
3. Keeping their houses and out-houses clean inside and whitewashed outside.
4. Instruction in sewing and mending and keeping care of clothing.
5. Looking after the sick and the isolation of T.B. cases from the other members of the family.

In addition adult...........

In addition, adult classes would be held for mothers and expectant mothers. There is a great deal of training needed here, as the infant mortality is very high.

We have in view, a nurse, who has had considerable experience with Indians and public health work. She is highly recommended by Dr. J. C. Gillie and the sisters of the St. Joseph's Boarding school. She has nursed and also taught Junior work at this school. Besides having done well along academic lines, the teacher has done particularly good work in the teaching of sewing and cooking - so much so that older girls who had left school have returned for the lessons in domestic arts. The way in which Miss Graham has had her regular pupils; the older part-time girls; and the married women, convert old worn-out military clothing into worth-while garments for wear on the reserve deserves special mention.

Mr. Agent Burk and I have tried to persuade her to return to Gull Bay next year. That she will do so, however, is not too certain, since the scarcity of qualified teachers is forcing salaries steadily upward.

It is appreciated that it is difficult for the Department to interfere with the salary schedule, but I was wondering if it would be possible to increase, from five dollars to ten dollars, the allowance made this teacher for the dispensing of medicines. I may say that I enquired as to the amount of time spent by Miss Graham in this dispensary work, and was told that it was unusual if she were allowed to get a full night's sleep during the winter, without someone calling for medicine or attention. She claims to have spent over one hundred hours some months in dispensing medicines or visiting sick Indians. This would make her remuneration for this work about five cents per hour.

I dislike interfering in the question of salaries, as it is none of my business, but having watched the work being done by unqualified teachers in the east, where the teachers were really trying to do their best but were obviously untrained, I would prefer to make it worthwhile for our trained teachers to remain with us.

8th instant in connection with other matters, the above was
discussed. He advised that the complaint involved some damage

guilty parties were known by her and could be identified, so
he was taking the Magistrate to the reservation in order that
the matter could be disposed of at once.

On the 10th instant a telegram was rec'd from Mr. Burk
advising that plans had been changed to the 13th for the trip,

amounted to 3 panes of glass, 10" x 10" in school windows
broken, one door panel loosened, one of the lens of Miss

Miss GRAHAM'S eyeglasses were broken and she suffered max surface cuts on left eyelids. Miss GRAHAM was of the opinion that she was accidentally hit rather than with intent, the article with which she was hit probably being thrown at the school door, but intercepted by herself as she stepped out. She visited homes on the reserve and by the process of elimination believes the following persons are responsible:- Pat HAGLJIAK, Gilbert HAGLJIAK and Sam BERNARD as they were not at home and all turned up together shortly afterwards at the Hudson Bay Post. These persons are not pupils of the school and range from 16 to 21 years of age. There are also 2 other persons who she was not sure of being on the reserve namely:- Abel BOUCHARD and Francis NAWLA.

Miss GRAHAM's statement reads as follows:

I, Miss Graham, hereby state that on evening of Thursday Sept.30th, when I was in the classroom someone threw something against the school twice. One object sounded like the footscraper. About half an hour later there was more banging. Then when I went to go out from the classroom door, an obstacle struck me, breaking my glasses. My face was cut in three places and my eye badly discolored. I chased the culprits, there were 3 of them. Then I went to the HAGLJIAK home. Pat and Gilbert were not there. When I went to Sam BERNARD'S home he was not there.

Mr. Macaulay, the Hudson Bay Factor stated that these 3 boys were in his store that night.

All the boys from the north side of the reserve were at their homes or visiting with their neighbors. Therefore there were only 5 who were not at home. I did not find out where Francis NAWLA was that night nor if Abel BOUCHARD and Norman BOUCHARD were on the Reserve that night.

(Margaret MacGraham)

All persons mentioned in Miss GRAHAM'S statement were not on the reserve, since having left to work in Camps of Pigeon Tbr-Cor, some 4 or 5 miles distance. Due to the fact that Magistrate LeMay wished to return same date and the boat was leaving, these persons could not be interviewed by this patrol. However a meeting was called of all the grown-ups on the reserve. No information was forthcoming from them as to the identity of the perpetrators. They were addressed by both the Magistrate and Mr. Burk on the importance of the school and instructed that they as parents should maintain sufficient discipline over their children to see that such things did not happen.

Patrol returned to MacDairmid and thence to Nipigon, leaving Gull Bay at approx 3 p.m. same date.

Further patrol will be made to Gull Bay at first opportunity for the purpose of interviewing those mentioned in Miss GRAHAM'S statement and further this investigation. May Delay please be set at 16-11-43.

1. Further to the marginally noted C.R. under the above heading, I have to report that on the 4th instant, Mr. Burk, Indian Agent, Fort Arthur, Ont., was contacted by telephone and arrangements made whereby the writer and S/Cst. D. Morriseau would patrol via Indian Dept. boat from MacDairmid to Gull Bay in a.m. of the 5th instant for the purpose of furthering this investigation.

2. Early a.m. of 5-11-43, the writer accompanied by S/Cst. Morriseau proceeded to MacDairmid with the Game Warden via his auto transport, gratis. On arrival the Captain of Indian Dept. boat was contacted and he advised that due to rough weather he would be unable to proceed to Gull Bay that date, but would pick us up in MacDairmid in a.m. of 6-11-43. At 9 a.m. of 6-11-43 patrol continued to Gull Bay via Indian Dept. boat.

3. On arrival at Gull Bay Indian Reserve same date, Pat and Gilbert Nawhiijik, suspects in this connection were sought out and interrogated individually. Pat Nawgiijik stated that he had not been near the school the night the school teacher had had her glasses broken. He maintained that the only place he had been other than his home was at the Hudson Bay store, which is situated at least ½ mile from the school, and that he had been accompanied there by one Alex Dubiskopens and a Sam Bernard. No information of assistance could be gained from him.

4. Gilbert Nawhiijik stated that he had spent the entire evening at the home of Martin Nawia playing cards with the Nawia children and that he had not been near the school. Persistent questioning failed to divulge any information of value from him.

5. Sam Bernard, another suspect mentioned by the teacher was not available for questioning, being absent from the reserve, setting out trap lines and not expected to return for at least 3 weeks. Alex Dubiskopens was also absent being similarly engaged.

6. Mr. McCaulley, Hudson Bay Factor, was interviewed and he stated that he recalled Pat Nawgiijik, Alex Dubiskopens and Sam Bernard having been in his store the night in question but was unable to set the time. The store usually closes at approx. 8 or 9:30 p.m.

7. On 7-11-43 investigation continued and the home of Martin Nawia was visited. Martin Nawia and his son Paul, mentioned by the school teacher as a suspect, were not at home being away on trap lines and not expected back for 3 weeks.

CONT'D PAGE (2)
7. (continued) A daughter, Jean WAWIA, approx. 20 years of age was at home with several younger children. She was questioned and stated that Gilbert NAWIGIJIK had been at their home on the night that the school teacher had had her glasses broken. He had been with Alex DUBISIERS and that they had left shortly before midnight. She was unable to state the time of their arrival but as DUBISIERS had also been in the Hudson Bay store it would appear that it might have been after the time set by the school teacher at which her glasses were broken. She further stated that her brother Francis WAWIA had not been on the reserve that night, having been away with her father.

8. P.M. of 7-11-43 patrol left Gull Bay to proceed to MacDairmid but after proceeding approx 12 miles we were forced to anchor in shelter to weather a severe blizzard, remaining there until the a.m. of 9-11-43 at which time we continued to MacDairmid, returning to the detachment via gratis livery in late P.M. same date.

9. While in MacDairmid on 9-11-43 Abel and Norman BOUCHRED, other persons suspected by the school teacher were located and interviewed. Both stated that they had not been near the reserve on the night in question having been in their winter camp, approx 4½ miles from the school.

10. On 7-11-43 while at the Reserve patrol checked the school and it was found that only 2 panes of glass had been broken rather than the 3 previously reported by Miss Graham. Miss Graham was re-interviewed and questioned. She stated that she had been under the impression that 3 panes of glass had been broken but had since observed that there were only two. It was further learned from her that one of the windows had been broken the Saturday previous to Sept.30th and the other on the Sunday following Sept.30th. It was also gathered that the door panel had been knocked previous to Sept.30th. Questioned more closely as to how her glasses had been broken, Miss Graham admitted that she couldn't swear that it was done by a thrown article and conceded that she might have broken them by running into the foot scrapper had it been hanging on the porch support outside the door through which she stepped when investigating the noises she had heard.

11. The Indians interviewed maintained that one of the windows was broken a considerable time ago, having been done by a painter pushing his brush through it. They also claimed that Miss GRAHAM had told several different stories the night her glasses were broken, the first to the effect that she had been hit by some boys and her glasses broken, 2nd that some boys had thrown a rock throw a window where she was sitting and broke her glasses and 3rd that some boys had been teasing her and had broken her glasses with a stick.

12. Information was received that Miss GRAHAM attempts to keep the children off the school grounds after school is over and that some of the older boys are inclined to tease her because of this and it is believed that probably some of the boys did make a noise outside the school on night of Sept.30th to attract her attention, but that she broke her glasses by running into some object rather than by anything thrown by them.

13. During the course of this enquiry S/Cst. KORRISEAU carries on general conversation with the majority of the Indians on the reserve and he states that there appears to be a general feeling of resentment among the Indians against Miss Graham, due, according to them to her inquisitiveness into their personal affairs and her officious attitude towards the people on the reserve. This attitude on the part of the Indians would cause...
13. (cont'd) cause them to shield anyone of their number that Miss GRAHAM attempted to get into trouble.

14. From the foregoing it would appear difficult to establish an 'offence' let alone securing sufficient evidence to prosecute the alleged offenders, in view of which investigation will be considered closed, unless otherwise instructed.

It is no easy matter, however, in these days when schools which used to pay seven or eight hundred are now offering twelve, thirteen and fourteen hundred, and when schools at twelve hundred and fifty, quite near large centres, are going a-begging.

Mr. J.G. Burk, Indian Agent, Fort Arthur, Ontario,

The Department is in receipt of Inspector Greening's report on his visit to the Gull Bay Day School on June 17th.

Memorandum:

Inspection Report
Gull Bay Indian Day School

Date of Inspection - September 27, 1949.

TEACHER - Mrs. Kibbee assumed her duties at this school effective 1 September. She is a nervous and excitable type and is sincere in her efforts to make a success of her new position. She is qualified and has the necessary experience. There are only a few pupils in attendance as the main body of the Indians is not yet moved over to Gull Bay from the town of MacDiarmid.

SITUATION OF SCHOOL - This school is situated on Lake Nipigon and is quite isolated. There is a new logging road to within three miles of the school but supplies all have to come across the lake from MacDiarmid. The mail is sent in care of R. Mills Store at this point.

The Hudson's Bay store has been moved to within a mile of the school and this provides a source of supply for the teacher as well as social company.

SCHOOL BUILDING - This is the standard 1930 design with attached teacher's residence. It has a full basement with a furnace in poor repair. The chimney is also in need of renovation. The teacherage has two bedrooms upstairs with a living-room and kitchen downstairs. We are providing new furniture and this should be a comfortable little school when the renovations are completed. It will need painting or lining with insul brick next year.

CLASSROOM ACTIVITIES - Unfortunately, I was unable to complete the inspection of this school due to the fact that weather conditions prevented our stay. I was accompanied by the Provincial School Inspector Mr. Greening, and it was evident that Mrs. Kibbee should do a good job if she will show a little more patience with the children. We spent some time discussing classroom problems and she seemed relieved by the advise we were able to give her.

Bernard F. Neary,

Ottawa, September 20, 1926.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 15th instant, enclosing communications signed by the chief and councillors of the Gull Bay Band requesting that the school be reopened on the Gull Bay Indian Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that your recommendation that a temporary school be opened for the coming winter months at this point is approved, and you may arrange to obtain the services of the Indian referred to by you as teacher. We note that his services can be obtained at the rate of $40 per teaching month. The Department will allow him salary at that rate during the period he has the school in operation. You may, therefore, make the necessary arrangements to have this school reopened at the earliest possible date.

Should any minor repairs or cleaning of the old building be required, you may arrange to have the work carried out, keeping all expenses for the purpose as low as possible.

You should forward a requisition at an early date for any supplies or furnishings that may be required, and only the supplies absolutely necessary should be asked for.

A requisition should also be forwarded for the classroom supplies considered necessary.

Should it be necessary to purchase fuel, you may arrange to have the quantity required supplied.

Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering all expenditures incurred.

Your recommendation that a new school building be erected at this point similar to the one that the Department erected on the Pic Reserve has been noted. An item will be included in our estimates for the next fiscal year to provide the funds required for the purpose.

Please inform the Department when you have concluded arrangements for the reopening of the school and state the date when the teacher began duties. This matter should receive your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur,
Ont.

Ottawa, November 14, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, informing the Department that you have, on the recommendation of Rev. Jos. Couture, appointed Miss Florence Morriseau as teacher of the Gull Bay Indian Day School.

The Department will approve of the appointment of Miss Morriseau, with salary at the rate of $40 per teaching month. We understand that she is an eighteen year old Indian girl, who attended the Lake Helen Indian Day School, and that she has no special qualifications. Her retention in the position will depend entirely upon the success with which she meets in the work, and on the occasion of your next visit to Gull Bay, you should report on the success which she is accomplishing. We note that she began duties on the 2nd instant.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 10th instant, I beg to say that the Department approves the transfer of Miss Doreen Ross as teacher of the Gull Bay Indian Day School. She will be allowed salary at the rate of $90 a teaching month. The transfer of Mr. Geo. W. Vesey from Gull Bay to Lake Helen is also approved. His salary will be at the rate of $85 a teaching month.

As you were informed in our telegram of the 13th instant, present regulations do not permit our changing the salary ratings at Indian day schools, and the salaries mentioned above are the same as were allowed teachers at these two schools during the past year.

In future, you should, at the end of each academic year, make definite enquiries from the teachers of the Indian day schools in your Agency regarding their intention of returning to their respective schools after the holidays. If any teachers are resigning or you consider transfers advisable, the Department should be so informed, in order that your recommendations may be considered in due time, and thus avoid the many difficulties that have arisen this year due to the fact that the Department was not informed until the time had arrived to reopen the schools.

Sir:

With reference to that portion of your letter of the 13th instant relative to the erection of a new school and teacher's residence on the Gull Bay Reserve, I beg to say that as the school at this point has not been in operation for sometime, it is considered that it might first be advisable to conduct a summer school with a view to ascertaining whether the Indians would take advantage of the opportunity and have their children attend regularly. We will have no funds next summer with which to erect a building at this point, but, if a suitable house could be obtained in which to carry on classroom activities, we would be prepared to provide for the salary of a teacher and the other necessary expense in conducting a summer school. You might give the matter of a summer school at this point your consideration and report later as to whether you would advise that same be conducted or not and also as to what accommodation could be provided.

Your obedient servant,

Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

MEMORANDUM

Dr. Scott,

When visiting the Gull Bay Reserve last July the Indians asked that the School be re-opened, in fact they have been pressing for this for sometime, and one has only to visit this reserve to see the necessity for it. There are about 35 children of school age running around like little wild animals with no restraint upon them whatever, and their parents declare they have no control over them. The little old building that was formerly used as a school house is quite unsuitable to re-open a school in as it is much too small and beyond repair and has no accommodation for a teacher. What is required is a building similar to the one erected this year at Heron Bay which combines a School house and Teachers' residence, and cost about $5,500.00, and is a credit to those concerned in its construction. It has been economically built. The cost of a similar building at Gull Bay would be somewhat greater as all materials would have to be transported up the Lake from the Railway about 50 miles.

If the Foreman-Carpenter who built the Heron Bay School was given a similar job at Gull Bay it would be erected with due economy as his work proved to be very satisfactory.

A proper person at this Reserve as Teacher would have a good effect upon the Indians generally as they are getting rather out of hand, making "Home Brew", etc., and the Agent requires some one he can trust to advise him from time to time of how the Indians are behaving and to issue rations.

As these Indians live by hunting and fishing their children require only an Indian Day School Education.

I promised the Indians to lay this matter before you, and I hope that provision will be made in the next Estimates.

Chief Accountant.
Ottawa, September 20, 1926.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 15th inst., enclosing communications signed by the chief and councillors of the Gull Bay Band requesting that the school be reopened on the Gull Bay Indian Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that your recommendation that a temporary school be opened for the coming winter months at this point is approved, and you may arrange to obtain the services of the Indian referred to by you as teacher. We note that his services can be obtained at the rate of $40 per teaching month. The Department will allow him salary at that rate during the period he has the school in operation. You may, therefore, make the necessary arrangements to have this school reopened at the earliest possible date.

Should any minor repairs or cleaning of the old building be required, you may arrange to have the work carried out, keeping all expenses for the purpose as low as possible.

When the bells arrive, you should arrange to have them taken to the schools and installed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Sir:

With reference to Christmas trees for the Indian children in this Agency, I beg to report I have received several communications regarding funds for the Christmas tree entertainment. As this year has been a particularly hard year for the Indians I would suggest, and strongly recommend, that the necessary permission be granted to purchase gifts for the school children in this Agency.

The teachers advised me all the children look forward to the annual Christmas tree, as it is the only Christmas entertainment of any kind in which they participate.

I would suggest that the grants be allowed for the following schools:

- Mission Bay School $15.00
- Lake Helen School $15.00
- Sand Point School $15.00
- Pic Indian School $15.00
- Gull Bay School $10.00
- Moberg School $10.00
