Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find duplicate voucher covering the cost of the construction of the Gull Bay Indian Day School, Gull Bay Reserve. The material for this school was shipped to Orient Bay where same was loaded into scows and towed to Gull Bay Reserve—a distance of 72 miles. The loading and reloading of lumber and freight charges increased the cost of building this school.

Owing to Gull Bay being very shallow the lumber was unloaded a mile from shore and transported in small boats to the Reserve, and then hauled by wagon to the school site, which also increased the expense.

The sand and gravel was obtained 7 miles from the Reserve and conveyed to the school site in canoes.

I have been unable to secure accounts from C. W. Cox for one scow load of lumber towed from Orient Bay to Gull Bay, but will send in this account as soon as possible.

As you will note by the enclosed voucher there is a balance of $274.40 still owing the contractor for wages. I would be pleased if the Department would mail a cheque covering this amount at their earliest possible convenience.

Sir:

With reference to the Gull Bay Indian Day School, which was constructed last year, I beg to report the old log schoolhouse which is in a very dilapidated condition should be torn down and removed from the school grounds, and there should also be a good substantial fence erected and considerable grading done.

The cost of erecting a new fence would be approximately $60.00. Removing the old log schoolhouse $25.00, grading the school grounds, approximately $75.00.

I would be pleased to receive the necessary permission to make the above mentioned improvements at the Department's earliest convenience.

Navigation will, no doubt, open on Lake Nipigon by the 15th of this month, and as I expect to visit Gull Bay by the first boat, I would appreciate the Department's views on this matter.

Ottawa, May 6th, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, relative to the moving of the old log schoolhouse, levelling the grounds and erecting a fence at the new Gull Bay Indian Day School, and giving an estimate of the cost of this work. In this connection I have to say that our funds for the present fiscal year are extremely limited and the above work will, therefore, have to stand over until next year. You might draw this matter to the attention of the Department again early in the Spring of 1931.

I have also your letter of the 3rd instant, relative to the request of the teacher to be furnished with garden seeds, garden tools, supplies for the teacher's living quarters and screens for the doors and windows. In this connection I have to say that the Department is doubtful as to the success of a garden at this school. I would point out that the school will be closed for the summer holidays during the two months when the garden would require the most attention. As our funds are extremely limited, I should be pleased if you would prepare another list of supplies for the teacher's living quarters, requesting only those items which are absolutely needed. You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of window screens for the school and teacher's residence, and screens for the porch door. No unnecessary expense, however, should be incurred, and an account, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the cost.

A football and a softball and bat will be ordered here and sent to the teacher's address, also a supply of tooth brushes.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to report, as a sanitary measure, Nurse Ings suggested that children attending Indian Day Schools, be supplied with cups, 2 wash baisins, for each school, 3 towels, and a supply of soap.

If the above meets with the Department's approval I can purchase same immediately and have the accounts rendered at the end of our fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, February 20, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, relative to the recommendation of Nurse Ings that cups, wash basins, towels, etc., be supplied for the use of the pupils attending the Indian day schools in your Agency.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery at each of the schools of 2 wash basins, 3 towels and a small supply of toilet soap, and 2 enamel drinking cups. The Department is not prepared to supply individual drinking cups, etc.

After the purchase has been made, you should forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, showing the expenditure incurred for each school separately. These accounts should not be rendered until after the 1st of April, next, as our funds for the balance of the present fiscal year are exhausted.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

August 5th, 1932.

Sir:

For the Department's information I wish to state the majority of the Indian Day Schools are equipped with oil stoves, and are very economical to operate where the schools are a short distance from the railway.

With reference to the Gull Bay and Grand Bay schools I wish to report both these schools are isolated. Under the circumstances I would strongly recommend that 2 inexpensive cook stoves be purchased, which will undoubtedly pay for themselves in 2 years time.

The approximate cost of 2 good substantial stoves will be $63.15. I would strongly recommend this purchase as wood is very easy to obtain on both these Reserves.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

L.G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, August 10, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, recommending that two inexpensive cook stoves be purchased — one for use at the Gull Bay Indian Day School and the other at the Grand Bay Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase, from a firm on the list to receive consideration, of two inexpensive stoves of a type which would be satisfactory, and forwarding of same to the schools. If any stove pipe is required, you may also obtain same and have it forwarded with the stoves.

Please obtain accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the stoves and expenses in forwarding same for each school separately. Receipts covering transportation charges should be attached to your certified vouchers covering the cost of the stoves.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Gull Bay Indian Reserve,
Macdiarmid, Ont.,
April 15, 1937.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

The question of drinking water on this reserve is of utmost importance. At present the water tastes so bad that one can hardly drink it without it turning the stomach. We go out about 600 feet on the bay for it, but it is terrible. There is no well on the reserve and I suggest the department have two wells dug to serve the twenty-five families living here.

Doreen M. Ross.
Ottawa, May 5th, 1937.

Dear Sir,-

In replying to a recent letter I directed to all teachers of Indian day schools, Miss D. M. Ross, teacher of the Gull Bay Indian Day School, requests that some provision be made for a supply of drinking water.

It appears that she has to secure her water from the bay and, at the present time, the taste of this water is very objectionable. Do you consider it possible to secure proper water if a well is dug at this school? If so, let me have an estimate of the cost.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey.
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.
Port Arthur, Ont.,
May 15, 1937.

Attention-Supt. Welfare & Training

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, file No. 9-2-1, in connection with a letter from Miss D. M. Ross requesting that some provision be made for the supply of drinking water at the Gull Bay Indian Reserve.

In reply I wish to report that it is impossible to drink the Lake water until it has been strained and allowed to settle, owing to the shallowness of the Lake at that point.

The ground formation consists of 12 ft. of sandy loam, and at this depth weeping clay is encountered and it is very difficult to make any kind of an accurate estimate as to the cost of sinking crib work etc. to permit the digging of a well. However, I would suggest that the sum of $100.00 be authorized to cover approximately 30 ft. of crib work etc. and the purchase of an inexpensive pump and fittings.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
EX'D.

Ottawa, May 20th, 1937.

Dear Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, with reference to making provision for a supply of drinking water at the Gull Bay Indian Day School.

Our experience regarding the digging of wells has been rather unfortunate. In many cases, considerable sums have been expended without an adequate supply being secured.

Unless you can assure us that a supply of drinking water can be secured for the Gull Bay School at a cost not exceeding $100.00, the Department will be unable to authorize your proceeding with this work.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Hudson's Bay factor at the Gull Bay reserve part of which I quote here, as follows:
"The cellar of the school here, is flooded within 2 feet of the ceiling and presents quite a problem. It will be necessary to start a gang of men on the job as soon as possible to locate the drain and remove the water."

I might add, in explanation, that since August 14th, with the exception of three days, we have had rain every day, in this District, and considerable damage has been caused.

I am unable to state just what expense will be involved to have the basement of the school at Gull Bay drained, and the furnace etc. put in operating condition, but would estimate it very roughly at $40.00. Port Arthur, Ont.,
November 18, 1941.

Attention-Supt. of Welfare & Training

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith, credit voucher No. 14-4, covering labour paylists on the draining of the basement at the Gull Bay Indian Day school.

In a previous letter, dated Oct. 6th, in which we reported the flooding of the basements of the Pic, Gull Bay and Mobert dayschool the cost of the work was estimated at approximately $40.00 for each school. Due to the urgency of the matter, at the time it was possible only to make a very rough estimate, and as it turned out, the Mobert school only cost $21.35, but the Gull Bay school has cost $139.20, however, with careful supervision on the total cost of the repairing, painting and draining, at each of these schools, I believe it will be possible to keep within the balance now on hand.

The high cost of doing this work at the Gull Bay school, was due to the fact that the soil surrounding the school is a type of weeping clay and it was found that before any excavating could be done it was necessary to cut timbers and brace the walls of the ditch or drain. In addition it was necessary to remove a large quantity of silt and debris from the basement itself.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.

Attention-Supt. of Welfare & Training

Dear Sir:

On my last inspection of the Gull Bay Indian day school I found it would be necessary to replace some glass in the windows of the residence and the classroom as well as a glass in the combination storm doors. New furnace pipes will also have to be installed and six blinds for the classroom are necessary. Glass and blinds will cost approximately $18.00 but I am unable to quote an estimate on the cost of the furnace pipe as it is necessary to have these made to order.

Would you kindly advise if it will be in order to proceed with the above repairs before the Fall term commences.

Yours very truly,

J. G. Burk,

When on a visit to the Sault last week I discussed with Mr. McNab, Indian Agent, the problem of dealing with health matters at Goulais Bay where I understand a school has been built and a school mistress is being appointed. At my suggestion Miss Mallon met me at the Indian office and we discussed this phase of the matter. I learned that she was for sometime a teacher in some Roman Catholic Institution in London and has done some nursing work. She appeared to be a woman of at least twenty-five years and capable. She had recently come to Canada and was nervous about going to a place where there were only Indians, but I fancy that if $100 were added for this work to the salary as teacher, that her fears would be overcome and that we likely would get a permanent employee in that isolated district. Sir,

I have the honor to report that I accompanied Miss Wilson & teacher to Goulais Bay Mission on the 7th Inst., and got her settled in her house. While there I had to make arrangements for the care taking of the school and also ordered lots of wood to be supplied. I find quite a lot of sickness among the Indians, mostly colds and the effects of having consumption in their systems. The greater part of the sickness is among the women and children. They are nearly all at work cutting Cordwood and Pulpwood. There is some of them in very hard circumstances they are asking me for relief. I made it plain to them that they would not get any relief from the department when they were able to get work. I made arrangements with the merchant at Goulais Bay that he would buy all the Cordwood and Pulpwood the Indians would sell out during the Winter and pay them a fair price for it, and give them supplies as they would have money coming to them. I told them in plain language they had to work or starve as the Dept. could not encourage laziness. I find that sympathy...

Dear Mr. McVatty,

I opened school on Monday the 13th, with an attendance of 14 and closed on Friday evening with the same, therefore, if this is kept up I expect good results.

The children appear fairly neat and clean, and are obedient, respectful and polite to a certain extent. They seldom if ever leave me alone, not even on Sunday or Saturday, always wanting to help; their favorite literature, all are very kind, but at times I would annoy their attention, however, I suppose we must do the inevitable.
Accompanied by two of my senior pupils I visited on Friday evening, some of the families on the Reserve, and in their few homes I found six persons very sick, four of whom are confined to the bed and are victims of that dreadful disease, consumption. Believe me, Mr. McNaught, if you were to visit some of these places you would not at all be surprised. Prince, I feel as though I had contracted the disease myself.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Early in January I took up the work here as Field Worker.
On my first trip I called at the homes of seven of the Indians
and to my surprise found six persons at the point of death, all
of whom died of Tuberculosis shortly afterwards. My next trip two
or three evenings later, I visited five of their homes and found six
suffering from Tuberculosis, all are living yet, but I expect four of them
will not last much longer. One of the ladies, Thomas Cadman,
formerly a teacher here, the other two may linger for some time.
All the other Indians on the Reserve appear to be enjoying good
health at present. The houses are kept in hot and ventilated
Pine Camp. I have insisted on their letting lots of fresh air, sun-
light and sunshine into their homes and the roofs of them all
were started to facilitate it. I saw when visiting, blinds taken off
the ceiling and walls, over the beds, inside hot stove, and I rec-
ommend, when all went to bed, the shutters dropped so as to keep all
fresh air out.

On opening school hours at 10.30 A.M., I always give
15 minutes for recreation and then open door and windows.
while all the pupils are out—This went on alright for a few days; then the caretaker, George Spackman, came along and ordered me, not to put them children out in the cold but they stay inside and play as they always did; however, next day I had all of them go out just the same and your humble servant along with them, though the caretaker and caretaker were not at all pleased—the former even ordered me to fill up the store of wood in the school and keep the windows and doors closed instead of opening as I did—However, a few days later the Doctor came to make his visit, and as the children in school he gave an excellent lecture on the good of fresh air, light, sunshine and outdoor recreation; since then, I do not think I could urge them to remain in school at recess—Before then you would seldom if ever see a woman or child out on the Reserve, but since they go out, and take the smaller children.

Dr. McEachern left medicine, along with directions for the men and women, old people, grown up girls and boys and school children—The latter ones have not lost any time out of school through sickness, before they were always so dull, headachy, pains etc., now they are lively and bright and attend school regularly. For the girls and boys out of school, men, women and old folks, many of them have told me if it was not for the medicine I gave them they would be in their beds—It has also done the children under six years of age a great deal of good.
The Indians keep their dead too long, usually three and four days inside a hot stove — I might safely say they start to mummify before burial — Neither do they bury them deep enough; the last one buried was only about four feet from the top of the coffin to the level of the ground and had been kept for three days and nights beside a cooking stove; the breath was hardly gone from her when her body became covered with little bugs.

Early in January, when visiting, I found two mothers who were nursing children that should be three and four years on their next birth day; the one with the four year old child has since passed it, but the other one who is a victim of tuberculosis has not, as yet, and she is in such poor health, coughing etc., that she is scarcely able to lift the child — She is one of the two that I spoke of in the beginning of this summary.

The Indians are, for the last week busy cleaning up their homes, yards, etc., and most of them are doing it very nicely.

Your obedient servant,

If they could be compelled to be more careful.

I have visited them when they would have hemorrhage so badly that they
would almost choke and what they would cough up would be like this.
This instead of being buried would be flung out on the chips and all
the hens, chickens, dogs, cats and other animals around would come
along and devour it in a twinkling. I have many times advised
them of the great danger. In any manner they are very careful.
Very often I pretend not to notice and then they do just as they have always been in the habit of doing.

I was where there was a young woman dying she could not get the physician up, her grandmother took the towel and assisted her, then she dipped the towel in the tea kettle on the stove and wiped the woman's hands and face and when through hung the towel up over the stove to dry, a few minutes later she was about to make tea out of the water the towel was dipped in etc. I explained to her and she appeared to be pleased with my explanation, cleaned out the kettle etc. but once I was out of her sight she would not practice.

I think they do not bury their dead deep enough — One morning went into the camp from the South end accompanied by a squaw and two children, a strong wind from the North was blowing, the odor was very pungent. To the squaw, there must be a cow or a horse dead around here, No, says she, it must be a dog — Would that the Department would order about one half of the dogs to be done away with as the small children near them do play toys, I mean the little dogs that are of no earthly use.

The school children appear to be quite well after their two months' holiday but are again in the same filthy condition as found them in January on coming here, their heads and bodies swarming with lice. wonders on them—Not one of the school children complain of being sick since I started to give them Dr. McEaige medicine. The Indians here are all fairly well at present, even in the consumption are doing nicely; there is only one now, who is not able to walk about outside. My pupil who was so poorly of the same disease is much improved and attends school regularly.

liquor house by the race and while this lasts there is nothing done among them but drinking and fighting.

On Monday night before Ash Wednesday they had a big dance at one of the Indian homes—On Sunday morning before two of the Indians drove to the Pass and brought home a case of liquor for the dancer, nearly all the Indians got drunk, fought in the house and outside—One of them, I believe, had some of his joints broken from his hands.

The next day a number of them came to me and uttered all kind of complaints, etc. I told them if they came for me, as Mrs. Marlet did at New Grass, when they were not within the fight, I could then have them punished but as they did not give me an invitation to see the fight, little could be done—They said they would come the next time.

The Indians say that up to New Grass, 1913, no one ever interfered with their fighting, drinking, going into houses, breaking, smashing, etc., that they always had done the like and it was a common thing to see the snow where they fought covered with blood and in a few days they would all be good friends, etc.

checked.

Mr. McHatt is doing his utmost to have them become better subjects — he certainly has work ahead of him as all his predecessors appear to have done but little; and moreover, I think care but little only get their pay and this makes it very hard now.

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo, in which you request an increase in your salary as teacher of the Goulais Bay Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to point out that you are now in receipt of salary at the rate of $800 per annum, plus a bonus during the present fiscal year of $15 per month, or a combined salary and bonus of $915 a year. You have only an Elementary Quebec Certificate, and it is considered that the salary you receive compares very favourably with that paid to teachers with your qualifications in the rural schools.

The inspector who visited your school on the 27th ultimo has given this Department a favourable report regarding your work. He has also drawn attention to the conditions at Goulais Bay in connection with your living accommodation and the condition of the school building. I may say that we have authorized Mr. Agent McNabb to purchase a quantity of supplies for the use of the teacher's residence, also to have a few minor repairs carried out to both the school and residence. We hope that the agent has made these purchases and that the various articles have been received by you, also that he is making arrangements to have the authorized repairs completed. We desire to make both the residence and school as comfortable as possible before the cold weather sets in; but we regret that we are unable to grant an increased salary at the present time.

We cannot approve of the school being conducted on Saturdays. It would not be fair to the children to ask them to attend on that day and, besides, it is against our regulations to allow teachers to teach Saturdays except in very exceptional cases when it is necessary to make up for a regular teaching day when the school was closed for satisfactory reasons.

Regarding the caretaking, I beg to say that if you will undertake this work, the Department will allow you salary at the rate of $40 per year. This will help to augment the salary which you receive as teacher. We will inform Mr. Agent McNabb of the amount allowed you for doing the caretaking, which will be paid quarterly, upon receipt of vouchers from him for the amount due each quarter at the above rate.

We hope that you will remain at this school and that conditions will be greatly improved when the supplies ordered arrive and the few repairs are made.

Sir:

Re: Patrol to Goulais Indian Mission.

I have the honour to report that on the 7th inst., C. H. Sims, local Indian Agent, informed me that as soon as the weather was fit and the roads in good shape he was making a trip with Gus. Nolan, Chief of the Batchewana Band of Indians to the above Mission to look into conditions there, as well as to investigate a complaint he had received about the School Teacher, he requested that I accompany him on this trip.

On account of the conditions of the roads and the ice being bad on the lake, we did not start until midnight of the 13th/14th, arriving at The Mission at 1.00 P.M. on the 14th inst. A meeting was called of all the members (both male and female) of the Band that afternoon and they were all present.

The first thing taken up was the complaint against the school teacher, Miss M. A. Gagnon. Mr. Sims produced a letter signed by Mrs. Ben Reil, Mrs. Alex. Neveu and Mrs. Mike Reil, Indians of this mission in which it stated that the teacher had been using the strap too much on the children, that she was teaching them bad things and that they wanted a new teacher.

I questioned these three women regarding the excessive use of the strap by the teacher but neither of them were able to state that any child had been strapped in a brutal manner, neither were they able to prove in any way that the teacher was teaching the children anything bad, in fact it seemed just the reverse. The Teacher, Miss Gagnon, was then called, she did not deny strapping some of the pupils, but stated that she had cause to do so, as some of them stole things from the school, wrote obscene words on the black-board and were generally disobedient, she also stated that it was necessary for her to wash some of the children, they were so dirty, this no doubt the parents objected to, after having heard the teacher, Mr. Sims asked if anyone present had anything else to say against as he did not think that there had been sufficient evidence brought forward to ask for the teacher's dismissal, no one had anything to say against her, but Alex. Robertson who is one of the best Indians in this district, stated that he had 4 children going to school at the Mission and that none of them had ever complained about being strapped, if they had he stated he would have looked into the matter and if the children were in the wrong he would have given them another licking, he further stated that Miss Gagnon was the best teacher they had ever had and that the children learnt more this last term than ever before.

A number of other Indians came forward and stated that Miss Gagnon was the best teacher they had had for 15 years and that they wanted her to stay.
After hearing both sides of the story, Mr. Sims informed the meeting that he thought the charges against the teacher were without foundation and were rather petty and that he would not take any action for the teacher's dismissal. Later he spoke to Miss Gagnon and told her to use a little diplomacy with the parents of the children. I talked with some of the Indians both before and after the meeting and they stated that the women making the complaints are sore at the teacher because she does not cater to them. Regarding this school, I might say that it is always kept clean and the attendance is good, there being 26 pupils on the register, all of whom attend regular and who are as far advanced as the majority of children of their age in the towns.

Sir,

re:- GOULAIS INDIAN MISSION SCHOOL
ATTENDANCE OF INDIAN CHILDREN AT:

I have the honour to report that whilst at The Goulais Indian Mission on January 18th and 19th, I visited the school to check up the attendance of the Children.

There are 33 pupils attending this school, an increase of 3 since the fall, the attendance at this school is very good, especially after taking into consideration the bad weather of the past month, when some of the smaller children were unable to get out of doors, most of the absences have been smaller children and a few of the larger ones suffering from colds, the average attendance per day has been around 22. The only children absent from causes above mentioned are, John Neveau, the son of Alex. Neveau, and Eli Neveau the son of Louis Neveau. I warned these people about sending their sons to school, their excuse being that they sometime wanted them at home to cut wood when the father is away fishing, they however promised to send them to school regularly in the future.

The School is in good shape, is clean and warm, and the pupils are learning very well, and there were no complaints from the parents. This school at present is the best Indian school in the District.

Micmac River
Jan 18th 7

Dear Mr. McNab,

Have been patiently awaiting cheque from the department. What is the matter? Have they refused payment? It seems strange. Every one in this locality has had "La Grippe" I suppose it is prevalent in the city too. I found the trip a hard one and the weather was exceedingly cold. Hope I shall be favorably from Dept. very soon, as I am considerably overdue. Hoping you are quite well and wishing you all success and gratification.

Yours sincerely,
Amos Kootenay
Sir,

I beg to enclose letter received from our old friend Miss Annie O'Conner, in reference to her salary for the last part of services as Teacher, I may say that her return was sent to the Department on Nov 16th, last, on the return she gave as her address, Bank of Montreal, Hull, Quebec.

If this money was sent to the Bank, they have failed to notify her of the fact. Kindly let me know so that I can keep Annie from worrying.

I have the honor to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent,

J. D. McLean Esq.,
Aest, Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.
Ottawa, January 19, 1917.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant enclosing a communication from Miss Annie O'Connor, late teacher of the Goulais Bay School, in reference to her salary for the period which she taught this school during the December quarter, last.

In reply I beg to say that a cheque for $82.50 in payment for 33 days services was sent Miss O'Connor, Bank of Montreal, Hull, Que., in November, last. She should apply to the bank regarding her salary.

Your obedient servant,

Aast. Deputy and Secretary.

A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

weathered
Doors and Windows:-
weathered, finish door and windows with five inch plain facings. One half sash to be put in at end of lean-to and made to slide.

Porch:-
The floor and roof of the porch shown on the drawings are to be constructed the same as the main building.

Front Platform:-
Provide and fix a platform and steps to the entrance door, floored with 1 1/2 inch stuff.

Provide and fix in position shown for chimney a 12 inch smoke stack of heavy galvanized iron 26 gauge with nine inch interior pipe, with stone or brick foundation set on bracket at height as shown on section plan, and to have cellar at roof to keep stack from wood-work.

Leave small hatch opening in ceiling 18 X 30 inches with hinged cover.

Make two pipe holes, one in school-room and one in living rooms with proper thimble.

Skirting &c:-
Skirt school-room with 1 inch tongued and grooved stuff 4 feet high, after one coat of plaster has been put on, and cap with 2 inch rounded nosing and 1 1/2 inch bevelled strip along the floor. Living rooms to have base board 8 inches high.

Plaster:-
Batten, lath and plaster the walls ceiling and partitions with two coats, including sand finish.

Plaster to be made of good stone lime and clean sharp sand and clean water, with a good proportion of cow hair mixed thoroughly together.

Painting:-
Knot, prime and paint with two coats of Sherwin and Williams Paint, or (if this cannot be had) with
Painting:— with good whitelead and boiled Linseed Oil, the inside dressed work, (not including floor) mixed with any suitable colour chosen by the officer in charge of the work, and for the outside work also paint the doors, windows (not the roof) the weather boards, roll and pinnacle.

Clothes Hooks:— Fix suitable strong clothes hooks where directed upon battens 5 x 1 1/2 inches, thirty in number, 5 feet from the floor.

Blackboards:— Supply and fix two blackboards of good and very dry stuff, painted with three coats of paint, 4 x 6 feet in size, to be put where directed.

General:— The whole of the work to be executed in a workmanlike manner, and subject to the inspection and final approval of the Indian Agent or other officer who may be appointed for the purpose. No extras will be allowed unless they have been recommended by the said Agent or other officer, and approved by the Department of Indian Affairs.

However, as soon as I am able to be out again, which will probably be in the course of a week, I will see that he makes payment in full. This matter has been a source of a great deal of annoyance to me. Mr. Holcombe did not receive his money for the Goulias Bay school until about the 7th of December last, as it lay some time in the Post Office here before I got the check for him, so that until that time he was correct in saying that he had not received it. I had previously advanced to him a portion, I think $20.00, for your wages and also the wages of Fraser, but apparently he did not give you any of it. I also had advanced him, before he received his money, out of my own pocket, the amount of the wages of the plasterers. Had you let me know in reasonable time instead of writing to the Department concerning the matter I could have held all your money from him without any trouble, but I never supposed for an instant that he had not paid you until I received your first letter. However, I shall see that Mr. Holcombe pays this as soon as I can possibly attend to it.

Yours truly,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of this date and number advising me of the complaint of John Lament at not receiving his pay for work done in Codiac Bay School last October.

In reply I beg to state that I am informed by Mr. Holcomb that this account has been verbally paid months ago, but owing to a disputed account no receipt had been obtained by Mr. Holcomb until I called his attention to the matter in my receipt of your letter.

I therefore enclose for your inspection Lament's receipt in full for wages in work done for Holcomb during the same period.
